fields.description:
As a cloud user I would like to be able to define bucket policies on my buckets that are enforced so that I can grant and restrict access from other users and accounts to my buckets.

Acceptance:
GIVEN an authenticated user and existing bucket WHEN the user sets a bucket policy or gets a bucket policy THEN the policy is applied (if set) or returned (if retrieved).

  
http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/UsingBucketPolicies.html

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/using-iam-policies.html
fields.summary: Object Storage support for bucket policies

Originally posted on 2012-03-15 22:05:11

Thu Mar 15 15:05:10 2012: Request 2750 was acted upon.
 Transaction: Queue changed from Feature Requests to Engineering Bugs by neil
       Queue: Engineering Bugs
     Subject: walrus: backend support for bucket policies
       Owner: neil
  Requestors: neil@eucalyptus.com
      Status: open
 Ticket <URL: https://support.eucalyptus.com/Ticket/Display.html?id=2750 >


This transaction appears to have no content
moving to investigating so we can review during our eng-support bug scrub.

S3 supports three types of permissions:  bucket ACLs, IAM policies, and bucket policies.  This bug is about the latter; Walrus's IAM support already exists.  [~wenye]'s comment indicates that one can use Eucalyptus's IAM machinery to implement bucket policies, not that IAM policies aren't supported.

[~gholms] is correct. Walrus does all of the regular S3 IAM stuff, just not the "bucket policies" which are a different type of IAM policy that is loaded specifically to the bucket, not through normal IAM APIs.

As an example, the IAM policy is set on EC2 and is defined by the account owner and user. That policy specifies that userX can do actions: A,B,C on resources X,Y,Z. We already support S3 operations in our IAM implementation, so IAM policies can specify actions like PutObject, ListBucket, etc.

Bucket policies are set in S3 on a specific bucket (you must upload the policy doc to the bucket using PUT /bucket/?policy) that is only set by the bucket owner. It specifies that for bucket B, user X can do operations Y,Z,A. and user T can do operations E,F,G.

[~gholms],

Thanks for the clarification.  Makes total sense.  

Cheers,

Harold Spencer, Jr.
This is a new feature, NOT a security vulnerability. S3 did not start out with support for bucket policies. This was introduced later.
I marked it as security-related feature. Note that having security set to "Yes" does not mean that this is a vulnerability.

Hey [~neil],

Yep, you are correct, they did add it later.  [July 2010|http://aws.amazon.com/about-aws/whats-new/2010/07/06/aws-management-console-adds-support-for-amazon-s3-2/] was when they added it. So, since we scoped it out for post 3.1 as indicated in the ticket, is this a new feature or an improvement (i.e. some aspects of it was added, but wasn't completely implemented)?  

_With this ticket, I guess what would help is if we had a list of what S3 features we currently support with Walrus, and what features we have scoped out next.  I think it would help clear up confusion regarding to type tagging. Thoughts?_ 

*UPDATE* [~zhill] hit me up with the goods here - https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/wiki/Walrus.  I looked at it but didn't see a definitive list..had to read more into the Walrus API section.  Gonna see if we can restructure that part to make it more apparent.

Btw, thanks Vika for labeling it as a security issue because it definitely is a security feature. Thanks for that.

We now support the S3 operations:

* DELETE Bucket policy
* GET Bucket policy
* PUT Bucket policy

As per:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTBucketOps.html

and runtime enforcement of bucket policies as described in:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/using-iam-policies.html
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/access-control-auth-workflow-bucket-operation.html
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/access-control-auth-workflow-object-operation.html
http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/access-policy-alternatives-guidelines.html
No longer under development
